pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Minerals</button> are the building blocks to <button class='glossary-text'>rocks</button> and provide us with clues about the history of the earth. Learning to identify minerals is a key first step in learning more about our dynamic planet. Although there are thousands of minerals on Earth, there are not many that are frequently found in rocks. The same mineral found in different parts of the world will look the same and have characteristic features and a consistent chemical composition. In this lab, students will learn how to differentiate between a mineral and a rock and to identify common minerals based on their physical properties by performing several diagnostic tests and making careful observations.

pageData.text: Many of the developments that have allowed smartphones to become commonplace rely on . For instance, the touchscreen of most phones has a glass display primarily made of silica, with sphalerite-derived indium and germanium making up the conductive “touch” LED display. As phones have gotten thinner, inks containing silver (derived from tetrahedrite) are used to print the connections for incredibly thin silicon (found in quartz) circuits. Similarly, new and improved batteries with longer life and faster charging rates are made from lithium (found in spodumene) and graphite1.

All these minerals are finite resources and must be extracted from the earth through mining, which exacts an enormous environmental toll. Many companies and organizations are working on ways to better recycle the minerals within old smart phones to reduce the need for continual mineral extraction.

pageData.text: People generally know that the earth is made out of and , but they do not often know the difference between them. The words mineral and rock have very specific meanings to geoscientists, often much more precise than those used in everyday language. To geoscientists, a mineral is a , , , with a and . If a substance fails to meet even one of the criteria, the substance is not classified as a mineral.

text: Naturally occurring means that minerals form by natural processes. Human-made materials like plastic, steel, and cubic zirconia are not minerals.

Inorganic means that minerals cannot contain organic carbon, which is a carbon atom bound to at least one hydrogen atom. However, minerals can contain inorganic carbon, which is formed when carbon bonds with elements other than hydrogen (i.e., calcium , CaCO3, which is more commonly known as the mineral calcite). Coal, for example, is not a mineral because it is composed of dead plant remains made of organic carbon.
Solid means that minerals retain their shape indefinitely under normal conditions. Therefore, liquids like oil and water and gases like air and propane are not minerals.

Definable chemical composition means that the elements present in a mineral and the proportions of their atoms can be expressed by a simple formula (for example, quartz is SiO2; calcite is CaCO3) or by one that is more complex, such as the mineral olivine, (Mg, Fe)2SiO4. The formula for olivine is both definite (two parts magnesium [Mg] or iron [Fe] atoms, one part silicon atoms, and 4 parts oxygen atoms) and variable, because magnesium and iron atoms are similar in size and have identical electrical charges, they are interchangeable in the crystalline structure of olivine. Thus, they can be present in any combination—all iron and no magnesium, or vice versa, or any ratio in between. The result can be an iron-rich olivine (tends to be brownish) or a magnesium-rich olivine (tends to be a brilliant green).
Homogenous means that a piece of a mineral contains the same pure material throughout.

Crystalline structure means that all minerals must have an internal grid of atoms that form an orderly, repeating, three-dimensional pattern. The crystalline structure of a mineral can be revealed by a mineral’s external crystal shape, which often mimics the internal geometric arrangement of atoms. The crystalline structure causes minerals to break in predicable patterns. For example, the mineral halite, NaCl (table salt), contains atoms of sodium (Na) and chloride (Cl) arranged in the shape of a cube (Figure 1). If you smash a block of halite with a hammer, it will break into many cubes (and rectangles) of all sizes.

pageData.text: Geologists have identified and classified over 4,000 <button class='glossary-text'>minerals</button> in the earth’s crust. They are perhaps nature’s most beautiful and diverse phenomena. Minerals occur in every color of the rainbow and in widely varied geometric shapes. Some minerals are harder than glass and steel; others are so soft that you can scratch them with your fingernail. Minerals sometimes occur as tiny specks of dust, but when viewed under a microscope, they are found to be composed of a tiny, repeating pattern of intricate crystals. Some minerals can bend light, taste salty or sour, catch fire, dissolve in water, and change color. Each of the 4,000-plus minerals that have been identified have a set of physical and chemical properties that are unique to them. A comprehensive list of all minerals that have been identified and their physical and chemical properties is compiled in a mineral reference book. Geologists then began classifying minerals into groups based on their physical and chemical properties. Why classify minerals? Because classification shows us relationships between things that may lead us to understand them and the processes by which they were made.

In the earth, most minerals are found as parts of . It is important to know the difference between a mineral specimen and a rock. A rock is a coherent, consisting of an aggregate of minerals, pieces of pre-existing rocks, volcanic glass, or even a mass of organic material. Some rocks, like granite, contain grains of several different minerals; and some, like rock salt, are made of many grains of a single mineral. Others are made of fragments of previously existing rock that are cemented together or from volcanic glass that cooled so quickly from a molten state that their atoms did not have time to form the internal grid-like found in minerals. Granite, an igneous rock, is an aggregate of several common (Figure 2), including (A) biotite mica (black), (B) plagioclase feldspar (gray or white), (C) quartz (clear or white), and (D) potassium feldspar (pink).

pageData.subTitle: Mineral Classification
pageData.text: The 4,000-plus that have been identified are often classified into smaller groups according to their importance, use, chemical makeup, or physical properties. For example, a group of only about thirty minerals are known as , because they are the minerals that combine to form the that make up most of the earth’s crust. Rock-forming minerals are the most common minerals on the planet; they are everywhere—not only in the rocks but also in soils and sediments, and even in the dust that we breathe. Examples of rock-forming minerals include: quartz, calcite, feldspars, micas, amphibole, and pyroxene. Because they are ubiquitous, rock-forming minerals are inexpensive but nevertheless economically vital; you rely on them every day when you drive on a paved road or enter a concrete building or your home.

Another group of minerals is called the . Though they are less common and typically present in lesser abundance than the rock-forming minerals, industrial minerals are important economically because they are the main non-fuel raw materials used to sustain industrialized societies like ours. One example of an industrial mineral is apatite [Ca5(PO4)3(F,OH)], which supplies the phosphorous needed to manufacture agricultural fertilizers and is also one of the fundamental compounds in your bones and tooth enamel.

Another subclass of minerals is the <button class='glossary-text'>ore minerals</button>. To be classified as an ore mineral, the mineral must be composed of elements, including metals, that can be economically extracted (mined) for profit. Examples of ore minerals include galena (PbS), which is the main source of lead, and chalcopyrite (CuFeS<sub>2</sub>), which is the principal source of copper.
Geologists also classify minerals into a small number of groups based on the anion in their chemical composition. These groups include:

text: are composed of pure silicon dioxide (SiO2, called quartz) or silicon-oxygen ions [(SiO4)4-] combined with other elements. Examples are potassium feldspar, KAlSi3O8; biotite, K(Mg,Fe2+3)(Al,Fe3+)Si3O10(OH,F)2; and olivine, (Fe,Mg)2SiO4.

<button class='glossary-text'>Oxides</button> contain oxygen (O<sup>2-</sup>) bonded to a metal (except silicon). Examples are corundum, Al<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>; hematite, Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>; and magnetite, Fe<sub>3</sub>O<sub>4</sub>.
<button class='glossary-text'>Sulfides</button> contain sulfur ions (S<sup>2-</sup>) bonded with metal(s) and no oxygen. Examples are galena, PbS; pyrite, FeS<sub>2</sub>; and sphalerite, ZnS.
<button class='glossary-text'>Sulfates</button> contain sulfate ions (SO<sub>4</sub>)<sup>2-</sup> bonded with other elements. Examples include barite, BaSO<sub>4</sub>, and gypsum, CaSO<sub>4</sub>.

<button class='glossary-text'>Carbonates</button> contain carbonate ions (CO<sub>3</sub>)<sup>2-</sup> combined with other elements. Examples include calcite, CaCO<sub>3</sub>, and dolomite, CaMg(CO<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>. These minerals react with acid the way baking soda reacts with vinegar. Geologists use a dilute acid to detect carbonate minerals. If a mineral reacts (fizzes) with the acid, then it is a carbonate mineral.

<button class='glossary-text'>Halides</button> contain a halogen ion (F-, Cl-, Br-, or I-) combined with a metal. The halogens make up the second column from the right in the periodic table. Examples include halite (NaCl) and fluorite (CaF<sub>2</sub>).
<button class='glossary-text'>Native elements</button> are in pure form and are not combined with different elements. Examples are copper, Cu; gold, Au; graphite, C; silver, Ag; and sulfur, S.

pageData.subTitle: Physical Properties of Minerals
pageData.text: By definition, every has its own unique chemical composition and . These two entities in turn determine a mineral’s physical properties. The physical properties of a mineral are its characteristics that can be observed (and sometimes measured), which includes how it looks (color and ), breaks ( or ), feels, smells, and even tastes. Some minerals are colorless and nearly transparent, while others are opaque and dark colored. Some are dull and some are shiny. Some are hard and others are soft. Some form long, needlelike crystals while others form blocky cubes. Geologists use physical properties to identify minerals, much like police detectives use descriptions to identify suspects. Some physical properties are diagnostic and others are ambiguous.

<button class='glossary-text'>Diagnostic properties</button> are those that immediately help identify an unknown mineral or rule it out as a possibility. In our police detective analogy, examples of diagnostic properties that could be used to identify our suspect include height, eye color, shoe size, and the presence of birthmarks or scars. <button class='glossary-text'>Ambiguous properties</button> may vary in different samples of the same mineral. Color is a notoriously ambiguous property in many minerals. Hair color, weight, and style of dress would be examples of ambiguous physical properties that could be used to describe a human suspect.

It is important to note that no matter how diagnostic a physical property may be to a mineral, a single property cannot identify a mineral sample by itself. Rather, we must rely on several diagnostic properties to reach this goal.

pageData.subTitle: Luster
pageData.text: One of the first things we notice when we pick up a mineral is its luster. Luster refers to the quality and intensity of light that reflects from a mineral. For mineral identification, luster is divided into two main types—metallic and nonmetallic—that vary in intensity from bright (very reflective, shiny, polished) to dull (not very reflective, not shiny, not polished). For example, look around your home for objects that are made of metal (such as coins, jewelry, faucets, keys, door hinges, aluminum foil, knives, etc.). All the items selected will display a . Yet, the metallic objects can vary from bright (very reflective—like polished jewelry, the polished side of aluminum foil, or new coins) to dull (nonreflective—like unpolished jewelry or door hinges). Minerals with metallic luster reflect light just like the metal objects in your home—they have opaque, reflective surfaces with a silvery, gold, brassy, or coppery sheen. All other minerals have a nonmetallic luster—a luster unlike that of the metal objects in your home. Minerals with a nonmetallic luster look glassy (vitreous, very reflective), waxy, silky, pearly, or earthy (dull and powdery like dirt).

pageData.subTitle: Color
pageData.text: The color we see when we look at a is controlled by how the different wavelengths of visible light are absorbed or reflected by the mineral’s atoms. Color may be a mineral’s most obvious characteristic, yet it is often unreliable for identifying nonmetallic minerals because some nonmetallic minerals, such as fluorite and quartz, exist in a variety of colors. For example, quartz may be clear, smoky gray, pink (rose quartz), yellow, brown, purple (known as amethyst), or milky white (Figure 3). The variations in color are caused by elemental impurities in the of a mineral. For example, rose quartz contains a very small amount of titanium.

pageData.subTitle: Streak
pageData.text: The of a mineral is the color of its powder, which we can determine by rubbing a mineral against an unglazed porcelain plate, called a streak plate. Streak and color are the same for most minerals, but for some they are different. In these cases, the streak is an important . A mineral’s color may vary widely, but its streak is generally the same for all samples, regardless of their color. If you encounter a mineral that is harder than the streak plate, it will scratch the streak plate and make a white streak of powder from the streak plate. The streak of such hard minerals can only be determined by crushing a tiny piece with a hammer (if available); otherwise, record the streak as unknown. In Figure 4, although samples A and B look very different, they are both samples of the mineral hematite. One of hematite’s most diagnostic physical properties is its reddish-brown streak, which stays consistent regardless of whether the sample varies in color or .

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Image showing two samples of the mineral hematite. One has a reddish-brown color and nonmetallic luster and the other has a grayish-silver color and metallic luster. A streak plate between the samples show that despite the differences in physical properties, the streak for each sample is reddish-brown.

A streak plate between the samples show that despite the differences in physical properties, the streak for each sample is reddish-brown.

pageData.subTitle: Hardness
pageData.text: A is a measure of its resistance to being scratched. In 1822, Friedrich Mohs, a German mineralogist, developed the scale of relative hardness that we still use today, using ten familiar minerals. He assigned a hardness of 10 to the hardest of all minerals (diamond) and hardness of 1 to the softest mineral (talc) (Table 1). This is a relative scale, meaning that a mineral can scratch those lower in the scale but cannot scratch those that are higher. It is not an absolute scale, in which diamond would be ten times harder than talc and corundum would be three times harder than calcite. The hardness of common materials that are readily available during field investigations, such as a fingernail (2.5), copper plated penny (3), window glass (5.5), or a plate (7) were determined using the Mohs hardness scale. These common items can be used to determine the relative hardness of a mineral. To do so, you will need to determine which common materials the mineral sample can scratch and which ones scratch it. The range between the mineral scratching and being scratched is the mineral’s relative hardness. For example, if a mineral scratches a penny, but fails to scratch the glass plate, it has a relative hardness of 3–5.5 (harder than the penny, but softer than the glass plate). When determining hardness comparisons, always remember that the harder mineral/object is the one that scratches, and the softer mineral/object is the one that is scratched.

When testing mineral hardness, it is important to use a fresh surface of the mineral that has not been affected by weathering. In some cases, it is easier to draw the unknown mineral sample across the hardness testing material; for example, scraping the mineral across a glass plate. In other cases, it is easier to draw the hardness testing material across the unknown mineral sample; for example, scratching the mineral with your fingernail. It is important to confuse a scratch on the mineral surface with a powder mark. A true scratch cannot be wiped off or rubbed away—it is a permanent indentation.

pageData.subTitle: Crystal Habit
pageData.text: The crystal shapes found in range from simple cubes with six faces (sides) to complex 12, 24, or even 48-sided crystals. Each mineral has its own unique diagnostic , or a preferred crystal shape, that is the outward reflection of the way that atoms or groups of atoms bonded together in a three-dimensional pattern (internal crystalline structure) as the crystal grew under specific environmental conditions and unimpeded by other crystals. For example, the habit of quartz is an elongated hexagonal crystal, topped by a six-sided pyramid. The habit of halite is a cube, while garnet’s crystal habit is a 12-sided crystal. It is important to note that while all minerals have a crystal habit, very few display it because crystal growth requires very special conditions (space to grow and specific pressure and temperature conditions).

pageData.subTitle: Mineral Breakage
pageData.text: If you took a box of mineral samples and broke them with a hammer or dropped them on the floor so that they shattered into smaller pieces, you would notice that minerals break in a variety of ways. Some break along smooth planes, others along curved surfaces, and still others in shapes. The way that a mineral breaks is controlled by whether there are zones of weak bonds in its internal . Luckily, instead of breaking the minerals in your set with a hammer, you can examine specimens to see how they have already broken using a magnifying glass to see more clearly.

is the tendency of some minerals to break (cleave) along flat, parallel surfaces. Cleavage occurs when chemical bonds holding atoms together are weaker in some directions than others. The mineral breaks along these zones of weakness, producing flat, smooth surfaces. Each set of parallel cleavage planes is referred to as a cleavage direction. Minerals can have more than one direction of cleavage. If there is more than one zone of weakness, the mineral cleaves in more than one direction. So, it is always important to note how many directions there are and the angles between those directions when describing a mineral’s cleavage. For example, micas cleave in one perfect plane, halite’s cleavage is described as three planes at 90°, while hornblende’s cleavage is described as two planes not at 90° (). To observe a mineral’s cleavage, hold it up to the light and slowly rotate it. Parallel cleavage surfaces will reflect light at the same time, making different cleavage directions easier to see.

Be careful not to confuse crystal faces and cleavage surfaces, even though they both are smooth flat planes; a cleavage surface is a breakage surface, whereas a crystal face is a growth surface. If you can see many small parallel faces, these are cleavage faces, because crystal faces are not repeated. In addition, breakage occurs after a crystal has grown, thus cleavage or <button class='glossary-text'>fracture</button> surfaces tend to appear less tarnished or altered than crystal faces.

pageData.subTitle: Fracture
pageData.text: refers to any break in a that does not occur along a plane. Fracture occurs where there are no zones of particularly weak chemical bonding within a mineral. Therefore, fracture surfaces are normally not flat and they never occur in parallel sets. Fracture can be described as (rough and uneven), (like elongated splinters of wood), or (ribbed, smoothly curved surfaces). Conchoidal fractures are common in thick glass and in minerals that have the same strength of a chemical bond in all directions, like quartz.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: If you took a box of mineral samples and broke them with a hammer or dropped them on the floor so that they shattered into smaller pieces, you would notice that minerals break in a variety of ways. Some break along smooth planes, others along curved surfaces, and still others in irregular shapes.  You can examine specimens to see how they have already broken using a magnifying glass to see more clearly. Cleavage is the tendency of some minerals to break (cleave) along flat, parallel surfaces. Cleavage occurs when chemical bonds holding atoms together are weaker in some directions than others. The mineral breaks along these zones of weakness, producing flat, smooth surfaces. Each set of parallel cleavage planes is referred to as a cleavage direction. Minerals can have more than one direction of cleavage. If there is more than one zone of weakness, the mineral cleaves in more than one direction. So, it is always important to note how many directions there are and the angles between those directions when describing a mineral’s cleavage. To observe a mineral’s cleavage, hold it up to the light and slowly rotate it. Parallel cleavage surfaces will reflect light at the same time, making different cleavage directions easier to see.

pageData.subTitle: Special Properties of Minerals
pageData.text: There are additional chemical and physical properties that can be useful in the identification of select that require geologists to use all five of their senses. However, they are too numerous to review them all. The following is a list of a handful of special properties that are typical of mineral groups or common minerals that you might encounter in your daily life.

text:
Reaction with Dilute Acetic Acid
All the minerals (minerals that have carbonate, CO3) will effervesce (fizz) when a drop of dilute acetic acid is applied to a freshly exposed surface. Calcite (CaCO3) is the most common example.

Magnetism
A few minerals are attracted to a magnet or act like a magnet and attract metal objects, like paper clips. The test is simple, check to see if a mineral is attracted to a magnet. The most common example is appropriately named magnetite. Other minerals, such as hematite, may also be weakly attracted to a magnet.

Tenacity
refers to the manner or way a material responds to being pushed, pulled, bent or sheared. Descriptions of mineral tenacity include brittleness (shatters like glass), can bend or be hammered into new shapes (like playdough or modeling clay), and flexibility (bends, but retains original shape). The mica minerals, biotite and muscovite, are examples of minerals that are flexible.

Feel
Some minerals, like talc and graphite, feel greasy or slippery when you rub your fingers over them. They feel this way because their chemical bonds are so weak in one direction that the pressure of your fingers is enough to break them and slide planes of atoms past one another.

typeBefore.text: Lay the samples and mineral identification tools out in front of you, so that you can familiarize yourself with them. For each of the 15 mineral samples, you will be completing the blank boxes in Data Table 1 by using the procedures outlined below. Then use the dichotomous key after Activity 1 to identify each unknown mineral and record its name in Data Table 1.

pageData.text: Luster Determine and record the mineral’s as metallic (M) or nonmetallic (NM). Metallic minerals are opaque and look like metal or similar to metal. Nonmetallic minerals do not look like metal; instead they are glassy (glossy reflection), waxy, pearly, or dull/earthy.
Color Determine and record the mineral’s color.
Streak Determine the of each mineral by performing a streak test. Use the white streak plate for darker colored minerals and the black streak plate for lighter-colored minerals.

text: Firmly drag the sample to be tested across the streak plate. If color can be distinguished, record the color in Data Table 1 in the streak column. If no color is left behind, try testing the sample on the opposite colored streak plate. If no color is left behind on either streak plate, but the streak plates are scratched, record “none applicable” (N/A) in the mineral’s streak box.

pageData.text: Take a photograph of each mineral with the streak on the streak plate.
Hardness Determine and record the mineral’s relative range.

text: Locate a smooth surface on the mineral.

Hold the sample firmly against a <button class='glossary-text'>solid</button> surface, such as a table. With your other hand, firmly press the edge of your fingernail against the sample and drag it across the smooth surface of the mineral. (This test may be inaccurate if your nails are painted or acrylic.) Gently brush the surface to remove any residue from the nail that may have been left behind. If there is a scratch on the sample, the mineral has a hardness of ≤2.5.
If there is no scratch on the sample, then repeat the above procedure using the edge of a penny. If there is a scratch on the sample, the mineral has a hardness of >2.5 and ≤3.

If there is no scratch on the sample, use the glass plate to test the mineral. Firmly hold the glass plate down on a flat surface, like a table with the index finger and thumb of your non-dominant hand. Then grip the sample in your dominant hand, and slide the mineral across the glass plate. If there is no scratch on the glass plate, the mineral’s hardness is >3 and <5.5.

If there is a scratch on the glass plate, the mineral has a hardness of ≥5.5, which can be further examined by using a streak plate. Firmly hold the streak plate on a flat surface, like a table with the index finger and thumb of your non-dominant hand. Then grip the sample, and slide it across the streak plate. If there is a scratch on the streak plate, the mineral has a hardness of ≥7. If there is no scratch on the streak plate, the mineral’s hardness is >5.5 and <7.
Record your results in Data Table 1.

pageData.text: Cleavage/Fracture Determine and record the mineral’s (if present) or (if present). Use the hand lens to observe each mineral more closely. For cleavage, determine the number of cleavage directions and the angle they meet (at 90° or not at 90°) or the name (example: cubic), if possible. For minerals that display fractures, specify as , , or , if possible.
Special Properties Determine and record whether each mineral displays any of the following special properties in Data Table 1.
Note: Wear your safety goggles, lab apron, and gloves while using the acetic acid.

text: Determine if the mineral reacts with acid. Place the mineral sample on top of several layers of paper towels. Add several drops of acetic acid to each mineral sample and wait several minutes. Look and listen for any evidence of bubbles, indicating a reaction and record your observations in Data Table 1.

Determine if the mineral displays magnetic attraction (strongly or weakly). Hold the magnet to the surface of the mineral. Record whether the mineral is attracted to the magnet and if the attraction feels strong or weak.
Examine the mineral’s <button class='glossary-text'>tenacity</button>. Record whether the sample is brittle, malleable, or flexible.
Examine the feel of the mineral sample. Record whether it has a unique feel or if it is greasy or slippery.
Determine if the mineral has a distinctive smell when scratched. Record your observations in Data Table 1.

data.title: Ambiguous property
data.content: A physical property of an object that varies between different samples of the same object

data.title: Carbonate
data.content: A type of mineral that contains carbonate ions (CO3)2- combined with other elements

data.title: Cleavage
data.content: The tendency of some minerals to break (cleave) along flat, parallel surfaces

data.title: Conchoidal
data.content: Ribbed, smoothly curved surface

data.title: Crystal habit
data.content: A mineral's preferred crystal shape, or the outward reflection of the way that atoms or groups of atoms are bonded together in a three-dimensional pattern

data.title: Crystalline structure
data.content: An internal grid of atoms that form an orderly, repeating, three-dimensional pattern

data.title: Definable chemical composition
data.content: The elements present and the proportions of their atoms can be expressed by a simple formula

data.title: Diagnostic property
data.content: A physical property of an object that immediately helps identify it or rule out other identities

data.title: Fibrous
data.content: Like elongated splinters of wood

data.title: Fracture
data.content: Any break in a mineral that does not occur along a cleavage plane

data.title: Halide
data.content: A type of mineral that contains a halogen ion (F-, Cl-, Br-, or I-) combined with a metal

data.title: Hardness
data.content: A measure of a mineral's resistance to being scratched

data.title: Homogenous
data.content: Contains the same pure material throughout

data.title: Industrial mineral
data.content: A mineral that is less common and typically present in lesser abundance than the rock-forming minerals; this mineral type is economically important as the main non-fuel raw materials used to sustain industrialized societies

data.title: Inorganic
data.content: Does not contain carbon hydrogen bonds

data.title: Irregular
data.content: Rough and uneven

data.title: Luster
data.content: The quality and intensity of light that reflects from a mineral

data.title: Metallic luster
data.content: A type of luster in which a mineral reflects light just like a metal object; mineral with this luster have opaque, reflective surfaces with a silvery, gold, brassy, or coppery sheen

data.title: Mineral
data.content: A naturally occurring, inorganic, homogeneous solid, with a definable chemical composition and crystalline structure

data.title: Native element
data.content: A type of mineral that is in pure form and is not combined with different elements

data.title: Naturally occurring
data.content: Formed by natural processes and not human made

data.title: Ore mineral
data.content: A mineral that is composed of elements, including metals, that can be economically extracted (mined) for profit

data.title: Oxide
data.content: A type of mineral that contains oxygen (O2-) bonded to a metal (except silicon)

data.title: Rock
data.content: A coherent, naturally occurring solid consisting of an aggregate of minerals, pieces of pre-existing rocks, volcanic glass, or even a mass of organic material

data.title: Rock-forming mineral
data.content: A mineral that combines with other rock-forming minerals to form the rocks that make up most of the earth’s crust

data.title: Silicate
data.content: A type of mineral composed of pure silicon dioxide (SiO2, called quartz) or silicon-oxygen ions [(SiO4)4-] combined with other elements

data.title: Solid
data.content: Firm and stable in shape; not liquid or fluid

data.title: Splintery
data.content: See Fibrous

data.title: Streak
data.content: The color of a mineral's powder produced when the mineral is rubbed against an unglazed porcelain plate

data.title: Sulfate
data.content: A type of mineral that contains sulfate ions (SO4)2- bonded with other elements

data.title: Sulfide
data.content: A type of mineral that contains sulfur ions (S2-) bonded with metal(s) and no oxygen

data.title: Tenacity
data.content: The manner or way a material responds to being pushed, pulled, bent or sheared
